When a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it is derived (for example, if it moves over a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return to the original place), it often finds itself in a different environment from that in which it was previously.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a powerful competitor compared to what it had before.
The population of origin has not changed at all, it still needs the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to resemble less and less the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will appear so different that they will no longer be considered members of the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense in which the fate of humanity is dictated by a underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technologies.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: technological development itself occurs according to a process that is far beyond cultural and political influences, and technology has an impact on societies that are intrinsically conditioned rather than socially conditioned.
For example, one could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a few cars, so new production methods are developed to reduce the cost of ownership of a car.

The possession of a large number of cars also leads to a greater incidence of accidents on the roads, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat the bodily injuries.

The use of ships for transporting goods is by far the most efficient way to move large quantities of people and goods across oceans.

One of the recent most remarkable examples of this situation was the North Atlantic campaign during World War II. The Americans tried to make it across the Atlantic to soldiers and equipment to help the British.
At the same time, the German Navy, using mainly U-Boats, tried to stop this traffic.

The "wagonways" were built in England as early as the 16th century.
Although the tracks were simply made of parallel boards, they allowed horses to reach higher speeds and carry heavier loads than the slightly more uneven roads of the day.
The crossbars were introduced fairly early to keep the runways in place. However, it soon became apparent that the runways would be more effective if they were fitted with a strip of iron on top.
It has become a common practice, but iron has caused more wear on the wooden wheels of the wagons.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first iron rails appeared.

Their predecessors, the australopithecines, did not walk upright as usual.

After its adoption by the Congress on 4 July, a manuscript signed by the President of the Congress John Hancock and the Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent to a few streets away, to the printing house of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, today known as "Dunlap Broadside".
The first public reading of the document took place in the courtyard of the Independence Hall on July 8.
One of them was sent to George Washington on July 6, who read it to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10.
The 25 Dunlap leaves still known to exist are the oldest copies of the document. The original handwritten manuscript has not survived.

Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and private vehicles between two points, and the interactions they exert between them.
Unfortunately, it is difficult to study traffic flow because drivers' behavior cannot be predicted with certainty.
Unfortunately, drivers tend to act within a reasonable range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonable coherence and can be approximated mathematically.
To better represent the traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) the flow, (2) the density and (3) the speed.
These relationships help to plan, design, and operate road facilities.

Content theories are centered on the search for what makes people feel good or attractive.

At the other end of the spectrum, one transforms into an unrecognizable individual who feels he or she must change everything that the group has created up until now and do things his or her own way.

Virtual teams are subject to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Virtual team members often function as the point of contact for their immediate physical group.
They often have more autonomy than traditional team members because their teams can meet according to different time zones, which may not be understood by their local management.
The presence of a real "invisible team" (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique feature of a virtual team.
The "invisible team" is the management team that each member reports to. They set standards for each of them.

Excursions are an integral part of any school class. Often, a teacher would like to take his or her students to places where a bus trip is not possible.

Practically participating in an excursion is also a great way to think about a trip and share your experiences with future generations.

For example, students at Bennet College in North Carolina design each year a website dedicated to their visit to the capital of the state. Each year, the website is updated, but the old versions are kept online to serve as an album.

Blogs can also help students improve their writing skills. Even though students often try the blogging experience with poor grammar and spelling, the fact of having a public audience usually improves the situation.
As students are often the most critical audience, the author of the blog begins to try to improve his writing to avoid criticism.
Moreover, blogging "obliges students to better understand the world around them". The need to attract the public's interest encourages students to be intelligent and interesting (Toto, 2004).
Blogs are a tool that stimulates collaboration and encourages students to extend their learning beyond the traditional school day.

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BC, and was used by Phoenicians, Romans and the Almohads as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who had destroyed it and rebuilt it and named it Casa Branca, abandoned it in 1755 after a earthquake.
The Sultan of Morocco rebuilt the city under the name of Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in Morocco for shopping.

Near the old medina, one can easily find places where one can buy traditional Moroccan products, such as tajines, pottery, leather goods, narguilés, and all kinds of souvenirs, but that's all for tourists.
Goma is a tourist town in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava of the Nyiragongo volcano which buried most of the city streets, especially the downtown.
Although Goma is reasonably safe, any visit outside of Goma must be done with caution to understand the ongoing fighting in the North Kivu province.
The city is also the starting point for the climb of the Nyiragongo Volcano and for gorilla tracking treks among the cheapest in Africa.
You can use boda-boda (motorcycle taxi) to move around Goma. The normal price (local) is about 500 Congolese francs for a short ride.
Combined with its relative remoteness, "Tombouctou" has become a metaphor for distant and exotic countries.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeast of South Africa and runs along the Mozambique border to the east, the Zimbabwe border to the north and the southern border is the Crocodile River.
The total surface of the park is 19,500 km², which is divided into 14 ecozones, each of which is home to a specific fauna.
It is one of the most famous amusement parks in South Africa and considered the crown jewel of South African National Parks (SANParks).
As for all national parks in South Africa, there are daily entry and conservation fees for the park.
It can be advantageous to buy a Wild Card that gives access to some South African parks, as well as all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island gives its name to the territory of Hong Kong and represents the main attraction for many tourists.

The Sundarbans are the largest coastal mangrove belt in the world, stretching 80 km (50 mi) from the coast to the backwaters of Bangladesh and India.
The Sundarbans were declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest located on Indian territory is called the Sundarbans National Park.
However, forests are not composed only of mangrove swamps. They also contain some of the last remnants of the majestic jungles that once covered the plains of the Ganges.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km², of which about one third is covered by water/marshy areas.
Sundarbans is a natural reserve since 1966, you can find about 400 Bengal tigers and 30,000 spotted deer.

The Oyapock Bridge is a suspension bridge. It overhangs the Oyapock River to connect the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers are 83 meters high; it is 378 meters long and has two 3.50-m wide lanes.
The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 metres. The structure was completed in August 2011, but it was opened to traffic in March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational in September 2017, when the Brazilian customs posts should be completed.
The Guarani were the most important indigenous group inhabiting what is now the east of Paraguay, living as semi-nomadic hunters and practicing subsistence agriculture.
Other indigenous tribes who inhabited the Chaco, such as the Guaycurú or the Payaguá, survived mainly through fishing, hunting, or gathering.
In the 16th century, Paraguay, formerly known as the "Giant Province of the Indies," was born from the meeting between Spanish conquerors and indigenous populations.
The Spaniards inaugurated the period of colonisation, which lasted three centuries.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Islands Pound (FKP), which is equivalent to a British pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank on the islands located at Stanley, opposite the FIC West store.
The pound sterling is a widely accepted currency in the islands, while at Stanley, American dollars and credit cards are also often accepted.

On the neighbouring islands, credit cards will probably not be accepted, even if British and American currency may be accepted. Make arrangements in advance with the owners to agree on a method of payment.
It is almost impossible to exchange money outside the islands, so change it before leaving the islands.

The stirrups are supports for the rider's feet, which hang from each side of the saddle.
They offer more stability to the user, but they can pose a security problem: in fact, the user's feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has a foot caught in the stirrup, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.

Violent weather is the generic term for any weather phenomenon that is dangerous to life, property, or society and that is likely to cause significant damage.
